name: Red Team Testing (RT) #2 - Testing methodology and scenarios
displayName: Red Team Testing (RT) #2 - Testing methodology and scenarios
description:
| Phase | Step | Outcome |
| ------------- |:-------------:| -----:|
| Red Team Testing Report  | 2 of 3 | Creation of the scenarios and methodology |

# Tasks

- `Task #1 - Create Scenarios`
- `Task #2 - Reconnaissance`
- `Task #3 - Weaponization`
- `Task #4 - Delivery`
- `Task #5 - Exploitation`
- `Task #6 - Installation`
- `Task #7 - C2`
- `Task #8 - Actions on Objectives`

# Scenarios

The red team should accommodate the scenarios written by the threat intelligence team and additionally generate new scenarios to execute.

# Outcome

Report with several scenarios, describing each action to be carried out for each phase of the kill chain. It is also advisable to indicate the tools that are going to be used in the report.

Also, if the scenarios can be represented in a standard format like Atomic it will be valuable.

tasks.title: Task #3 - Weaponization
tasks.description:
# Dependencies

This task has dependency on `Task #1 - Create Scenarios`

# Weaponization

Coupling a remote access trojan with an exploit into a deliverable payload, typically by means of an automated tool (weaponizer). Increasingly, client application data files such as Adobe Portable Document Format (PDF) or Microsoft Office documents serve as the weaponized deliverable.

Note that this phase in general hasn't impact on the victim infrastructure.


(*) **Create a task log for each generated procedure**

tasks.title: Task #2 - Reconnaissance
tasks.description:
# Dependencies

This task has dependency on `Task #1 - Create Scenarios`

# Reconnsaissance

Research, identification and selection of targets, often represented as crawling Internet websites such as conference proceedings and mailing lists for email addresses, social relationships, or information on specific technologies.

(*) **Create a task log for each generated procedure**

tasks.title: Task #4 - Delivery
tasks.description:
# Dependencies

This task has dependency on `Task #1 - Create Scenarios`

# Delivery

Transmission of the weapon to the targeted environment. The three most prevalent delivery vectors for weaponized payloads by APT actors, as observed by the Lockheed Martin Computer Incident Response Team (LM-CIRT) for the years 2004-2010, are email attachments, websites, and USB removable media.

(*) **Create a task log for each generated procedure**

tasks.title: Task #6 - Installation
tasks.description:
# Dependencies

This task has dependency on `Task #1 - Create Scenarios`

# Installation

Installation of a remote access trojan or backdoor on the victim system allows the adversary to maintain persistence inside the environment

(*) **Create a task log for each generated procedure**

tasks.title: Task #8 - Actions on Objectives
tasks.description:
# Dependencies

This task has dependency on `Task #1 - Create Scenarios`

# Actions on Objectives

Only now, after progressing through the first six phases, can intruders take actions to achieve their original objectives. Typically, this objective is data exfiltration which involves collecting, encrypting and extracting information from the victim environment; violations of data integrity or availability are potential objectives as well. Alternatively, the intruders may only desire access to the initial victim box for use as a hop point to compromise additional systems and move laterally inside the network

(*) **Create a task log for each generated procedure**

tasks.title: Task #1 - Create Scenarios
tasks.description:
# Dependencies

This task has dependency on GTL Report and TTI Report from the threat intelligence provider.

# Goal

The goal is to generate different scenarios to execute in the red teaming exercises against the `Entity`. As a reminder, the threat intelligence team had to previously generate scenarios, which are based on identified and real information about group attacks that could have some impact on the `Entity`. Ensure that the flags created by the threat intelligence team are in your scope.

The scenarios that are developed must be using the **Kill Chain**, indicating each activity that is going to be carried out in each phase. Of course, during execution, due to problems that could occur, the scenarios could be modified. All modifications must be documented in the report.

**It is vitally important to write scenarios from the attacker's point of view.**

All the steps that will be followed during the creation of the scenarios must be mapped with the ATT&CK MITRE matrix.

tasks.title: Task #5 - Exploitation
tasks.description:
# Dependencies

This task has dependency on `Task #1 - Create Scenarios`

# Exploitation

After the weapon is delivered to victim host, exploitation triggers intruders’ code. Most often, exploitation targets an application or operating system vulnerability, but it could also more simply exploit the users themselves or leverage an operating system feature that auto-executes code.

(*) **Create a task log for each generated procedure**

tasks.title: Task #7 - C2
tasks.description:
# Dependencies

This task has dependency on `Task #1 - Create Scenarios`

# C2

Typically, compromised hosts must beacon outbound to an Internet controller server to establish a C2 channel. APT malware especially requires manual interaction rather than conduct activity automatically. Once the C2 channel establishes, intruders have “hands on the keyboard” access inside the target environment

(*) **Create a task log for each generated procedure**
